PRICING STRATEGY

The 5-Minute Quote: How to Price a Paver Patio Accurately

By John D. August 3, 2025 8 min read

Table of Contents

Key Takeaways (TL;DR)

  • The Core Formula: Your price should always be Materials + Labor + Overhead + Profit. Never guess.
  • Material Costs: Always add a 10-15% waste factor for pavers and 15-20% for base materials.
  • Labor Costs: Calculate your total man-hours and multiply by your loaded hourly rate (your wage + taxes/insurance).
  • Profit is Not a Dirty Word: Aim for a 30-50% gross profit margin to ensure your business is healthy and growing.

Underbidding a paver patio is one of the fastest ways to lose money in the landscaping business. It’s a common mistake, born from guesswork and fear of scaring away a client. But a professional doesn't guess—they calculate. This guide will give you a simple, repeatable formula to price every paver patio job with confidence, ensuring you’re both competitive and, most importantly, profitable.

The Core Pricing Formula: Your Foundation for Profit

Before we touch a single paver, we need to understand the four pillars of any professional quote. Your final price to the client is not just a number you pull out of thin air; it's the sum of these four critical components:

Price = Total Material Cost + Total Labor Cost + Overhead Recovery + Target Profit

Forgetting even one of these components means you are paying to work for your client, not the other way around. Let's break each one down.

Step 1: Calculating Total Material Costs

This is more than just the cost of the pavers. You must account for every single item required to do the job right, plus a crucial waste factor.

Material Checklist

  1. Pavers: Calculate total square footage (Length x Width) and add 10-15% for cuts and potential breakage.
  2. Base Gravel (e.g., ¾" Crusher Run): Typically 4-6 inches deep. Calculate cubic yards needed and add 20% for compaction.
  3. Bedding Sand (e.g., Concrete Sand): Typically 1 inch deep. Calculate cubic yards and add 15% for compaction.
  4. Edge Restraint: Measure the total linear feet of the patio's perimeter.
  5. Polymeric Sand: Check the manufacturer's coverage chart based on your total square footage.

Example Material Cost Table

Material Quantity Needed Unit Cost Total Cost
Pavers (200 sq ft + 15%) 230 sq ft $5.00 / sq ft $1,150.00
Base Gravel (4" deep + 20%) 3.3 cubic yards $50.00 / yard $165.00
Bedding Sand (1" deep + 15%) 0.7 cubic yards $60.00 / yard $42.00
Edge Restraint 60 linear ft $2.00 / ft $120.00
Total Material Cost $1,477.00

Step 2: Calculating Total Labor Costs

Your time is your most valuable asset. To calculate labor, you need to estimate the total man-hours the job will take and multiply that by your "loaded" hourly rate.

What is a "Loaded" Hourly Rate?

This isn't just what you want to make per hour. It's your wage PLUS the cost of doing business (taxes, insurance, worker's comp, etc.). A simple way to estimate this is to take your desired hourly wage and multiply it by 1.3 to 1.5.

Step 3: Putting It All Together (Overhead & Profit)

With your material and labor costs calculated, you have your "break-even" number. Now, you need to add overhead and profit to build a healthy business.

A common method is to apply a percentage markup to your combined material and labor costs. This single markup covers both your general business overhead (truck, insurance, phone) and your target profit.
